awd_titl_txt: Implementation Project:  From Learning Community to Teaching Community - A Grass Roots Approach to STEM Undergraduate Teaching and Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Implementation Projects provide support to Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) to design, implement, study, and assess comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in STEM and enhance the quality of their preparation by strengthening STEM education and research. The project at Albany State University seeks to build on previous successful efforts to increase participation of African-American students in STEM disciplines. A component of the project is a Learning Community-as-Teaching Laboratory where faculty will focus on pedagogical approaches that best assist students to develop the skills needed for success in the STEM disciplines. The project will employ a cross-disciplinary approach, using faculty from both the natural sciences and education, who will employ evidence-based methods of teaching to enhance student learning.

The project has four specific goals:  1) to increase the number of entering freshmen in STEM majors; 2) to increase the STEM graduation rate; 3) to develop strong STEM skills, such as problem solving skills, critical thinking skills, research skills, and the application of the skills in the content areas in gatekeeper courses; and 4) to implement a professional development partnership in STEM teaching. The goals will be accomplished through faculty professional development, a support system for students, a learning community, and an integrated vertically aligned curriculum. The project seeks to create an intensive Sustained Support System for Students who are interested in STEM but who are at risk of not performing well and dropping out, providing them with the skills and motivation to persist in STEM majors. Through the evaluation plan, the project seeks to study the effects of these interconnected approaches as models for other HBCUs that are predominantly teaching institutions.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Title: HBCU-UP Implementation Project: From Learning Community to Teaching Community - A Grass Roots Approach to STEM Undergraduate Teaching and Learning.

 

PI: Seyed Roosta, PhD

Co-PI: Kwaichow Chan, PhD

 

Federal award number 1436060

Awardee: Albany State University

 

Major activities: The Albany State University HBCU-UP Implementation Project constructed a series of support structures for underrepresented STEM students in a rural south Georgia community. Activities included a high school ? college bridge program, cohort teaching for the first two years, directed advising plus curriculum sequence mapping/adjustments to keep students on a four-year path, mentoring, study groups, and teaching faculty development. The pandemic lengthened the project but allowed longitudinal data on student performance and graduation rates across four cohorts.

 

The team recruited the middle third performers from already-admitted students who had declared a STEM major. With slots for more students available than taken by summer program participants, additional students were added in the Fall semester to bring cohorts groups to the mid 20?s in number. By enrolling the Fall group students in with the summer program students in approximately even numbers, meanwhile involving everyone in the same project activities, the effect of the summer program was directly measurable. There was no clear indicator of academic improvement among summer participants over those added in the Fall. The highest impact of the summer program was seen in the social realm. Summer students tended to be leaders on campus, tended to be more successful at getting summer internships, tended to be more interested in research, and tended to mentor more students in the program.

 

During the academic terms, groups of 8-10 students were mentored by faculty members each week. As soon as the first cohort began their 3rd year, smaller cohort groups of peer mentors with 1st year students were formed. In this way, a continuous reinforcing community of teaching and learning was built.

 

Faculty members were encouraged to think across disciplinary boundaries. Multi-day workshops facilitated new cross-disciplinary teaching. They were also given 1:1 teaching assessments by experienced, external evaluators. Although this project element only resulted in new modules in a few courses, the broader conversation continued. Since, cross-disciplinary teaching has become more normal. HBCU-UP faculty lead the way.

 

Administrative buy-in and broad faculty support are essential for undergraduate teaching institutions and HBCUs wishing to implement such a large, complex program. This is especially important for new teaching in multi-disciplinary areas.

 

Project Results: The team targeted ten classes likely to cause the most problems in STEM students? first two years (Gen Chem I/II, Biology I/II, PreCalc, Calc 1, etc.) A uniform passing rate of 80% was set for these ?gatekeeping? classes. Of those 10 classes and across 4 cohorts (40  exemplars), only 14 did not make target. Given prior five-year baseline passing rates of 55-70%, this was a remarkable improvement.

 

Retention was also much improved. At 30 hours, HBCU-UP students improved over baseline data by 20% in Biology to 92% retained on average. In Chemistry, students improved 14% to 80% retained at 30 hours. In Computer Science, a slight 7% improvement was seen over baseline. In Math, the number of participants was too small.

 

Throughout, HBCU-UP student GPAs were improved over their STEM counterparts at the same institution. Program participants started out 0.6 points above their peers and never looked back. This head start had the added advantage of preventing the freshman cutoff after their second semester. All four cohorts dropped their grade point averages after the second semester, but none dropped below a 2.5. Most of their peer students were below 2.2. Four years on, HBCU-UP students continued to outperform their ASU counterparts with final average GPA of 3.45 against their peers at 3.08. This puts HBCU-UP students at a competitive advantage when seeking employment, entry to graduate school and access to scholarship/fellowship funds. In turn, they will tend to earn higher wages, get more desirable jobs and enjoy more success in their academic careers. 

 

Through the course of the project, 83 underrepresented students were served. To date, 44 have graduated, 39 with degrees in STEM. Many are already working in their fields, while others are enrolled in graduate and PhD programs. At four years, HBCU-UP STEM students graduated at an average rate of 32%, quadruple the overall rate for ASU. At six years, ASU students of all majors graduated at a rate of 35%. HBCU-UP STEM students in the first two cohorts graduated at 42% and 55% at six years. The five-year graduation rate for the third cohort is 52%. These ?on time? graduates moved to their next stage one to two years before their counterparts at whose matriculation time is closer to six years. As such, they can draw salaries, mentor other students and complete graduate degrees that much sooner.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2022
Modified by: Seyed Roosta
